body: We don't support Py3 yet. That said, you shouldn't have gotten to the point that you'd gotten a precompiled extension of the wrong ABI, and that you did is a bug that we'll be forced to get to when we do address Py3. :-/

Hi Masood,

Sorry to cause a problem, but I got another error but now with Python 2.7 as shown below. Is there  supported version list of gRPC for Java, Python, etc., as I looked on the Repository Structure & Status table on the [main repository page](https://github.com/grpc/grpc)?  

I got an undefined symbol `PyUnicodeUCS4_DecodeUTF8` with Python 2.7 in the shared library `cygrpc.so`.  It looks like the symbol definition is not there.  Though this is a known issue with prebuilt packages, as noted here:

https://docs.python.org/2.7/faq/extending.html#when-importing-module-x-why-do-i-get-undefined-symbol-pyunicodeucs2

But what packages would I need to rebuild?

I had the same experience -- the build appeared to succeed without errors on python 3.5.1, linux/amd64, with `GRPC_BUILD_WITH_CYTHON=1`, but cygrpc caused the same `SystemError` on import.

@pgrosu O_o
The only precompiled thing should _be_ UCS4, though. What does `print sys.maxunicode` output for you on your Python 2.7? If you have the time could you please try building a wheel of gRPC from source and tell me what the filename ends up being (you'll need the latest `setuptool` and `wheel` for the information to be useful, though :-| )? Also maybe what our `cygrpc.so` ends up getting named for your system?

Commands for your ease of copypasta:

Unicode:

```
$ python2.7 -c 'import sys; print sys.maxunicode'
```

Wheel and the expected cygrpc.so for your system:

_(prerequisites)_

```
$ pip install -I setuptools wheel pip
```

_(commands)_

```
$ git clone https://github.com/grpc/grpc
$ cd grpc
$ python2.7 setup.py bdist_wheel
$ python2.7 setup.py build_tagged_ext
$ ls dist/
```

@leifurhauks I think you meant `GRPC_PYTHON_BUILD_WITH_CYTHON`, and, same deal with Python 3 not yet being supported. :-/
@pgrosu Also, if you're blocked on this: to install without getting a potentially incorrect `cygrpc.so`, set the environment as `export GRPC_PYTHON_USE_PRECOMPILED_BINARIES=0`.

The problem, I _think_, is that a copy of `cygrpc.so` managed to slip into the source tarball of `grpcio` for version `0.13.0`. Despite  the installation package _correctly_ determining that there's nothing on GCS to download, the `cygrpc.so` present in the directory somehow confuses the process and fails to get rebuilt. We'll get this in the next patch.
@pgrosu I should note, too, that this means the suggestion I made to unblock you is utterly, horribly wrong. You're pretty much stuck installing from source right now. Sorry 'bout that!

Absolutely no worries @soltanmm, and thank you for all the help!  It's a fun research experience, and look forward to continue helping out on this :)  Feel free to ping me anytime, so we can continue with the goal of having the `greeter_server.py` and `greeter_client.py` example running.

Many thanks,
~p

@jacobkneal That isn't the error this particular issue is concerned with, but, funnily enough, this is something @sreecha just ran into (and I guess this holds true for both Ubuntu and Mac OS X machines): the environment variables are not copied over with `sudo`; `sudo` literally means 'run as super user' with all the unexpected things that entails. Here, it means that root's environment is used, not the current user's.

The expected edit might then be:

```
$ sudo su
# export GRPC_PYTHON_BUILD_WITH_CYTHON=1
# export GRPC_PYTHON_USE_PRECOMPILED_BINARIES=0
# pip install -r requirements.txt
# python2.7 setup.py bdist_wheel
# python2.7 setup.py build_tagged_ext
```
